questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Cueing/Posner task?

explanations.c: Correct! The main purpose of the Cueing/Posner task is to examine how attention is oriented and directed based on cues.

questions.question: How did the cues in the experiment affect your response times?

answers.a: Cues made no difference in my response times.
answers.b: Response times were faster when the cue was valid (correctly predicted the target location).
answers.c: Response times were slower when the cue was valid.
answers.d: I didn't notice any change in response times.

explanations.a: This isn't accurate. The valid cue should have improved response times.
explanations.b: Correct! When the cue was valid, participants responded faster because their attention was directed to the correct location.
explanations.c: This is incorrect. Valid cues should speed up response times, not slow them down.
explanations.d: This suggests a lack of awareness of the cueing effect. Valid cues should have made your response times faster.

questions.question: What did you learn about your attention during the experiment?

answers.a: I learned that I am equally fast at responding regardless of where the target appears.
answers.b: I learned that I respond faster when the cue correctly predicts the target location.
answers.c: I learned that my attention doesn't shift based on cues.
answers.d: I didn't notice anything about how my attention works.

explanations.a: This is not quite accurate. The experiment should have shown differences in response times based on cue validity.
explanations.b: Correct! When the cue accurately predicted the target location, you likely responded faster due to better-attuned attention.
explanations.c: This is incorrect. The experiment was designed to show how cues affect attention and response times.
explanations.d: This answer suggests that you may not have been aware of the experiment's effects on your attention.
